descriptionSet.description: In this image two women are seen, one of them playing the sitar while seated on a raised platform. Behind her a lake, clouds and a full moon can be seen. Beside the woman with the sitar, another woman can be seen holding her hair with her left hand and enjoying the music with her eyes closed. She stands in front of a pillar.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: In this image two women are seen, one of them playing the sitar while seated on a raised platform. Behind her a lake, clouds and a full moon can be seen. Beside the woman with the sitar, another woman can be seen holding her hair with her left hand and enjoying the music with her eyes closed. She stands in front of a pillar. (gs/sp)
text-en: Phoenix P. Works AHMEDABAD
text-en: Copy Rt. No. 237

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Here, the emphasis is on feminine beauty and simple domestic entertainment. Seen within that wider romantic genre, the Queen of Industry’s spinning becomes just another feminine amusement, on par with playing the sitar, meant to titillate the admiring male viewer rather than build up a national economy. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Finally and perhaps most interestingly, images of the modern home also promised women autonomy. In all the images discussed thus far, women appear on their own, free to spend their time as they please, whether reading a book, talking with friends, or sitting quietly in a chair doing nothing. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In these images no children demand attention, no husband asks to be served, no older women intervene to make decisions; the ubiquitous mother-in-law to which a young wife would have to give deference, has been banished from the scene. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)
